headline.main: Can I Let My Kid See 'Watchmen'?

docs.abstract: How to decide when it is O.K. for your child to see a movie?
docs.lead_paragraph: My 15-year-old wants to go see "Watchmen" tonight. The movie - the hottest teen thing since, well, the last hottest teen thing - is rated R. My 18-year-old saw it at the midnight show last night and said it was over-the-top brilliant, and over-the-top violent. My colleague A.O. Scott, who reviewed it here in the Times today, calls it a "grandiose, meticulously art-directed vision of blood, cruelty and metaphysical dread," and a "grim and grisly excursion into comic-book mythology."
docs.snippet: How to decide when it is O.K. for your child to see a movie?

headline.print_headline: Obese Teens As Likely As Smokers to Die Early, Study Finds
headline.main: Obese Teens as Likely as Smokers to Die Early, Study Finds

docs.lead_paragraph: Shorter life spans are linked to excess weight in youth, a long-term European study concludes.
docs.snippet: Shorter life spans are linked to excess weight in youth, a long-term European study concludes.

headline.main: Obese Teenagers Are as Likely to Die Prematurely as Heavy Smokers, Study Finds

docs.lead_paragraph: Likening obesity's risks to those of smoking, a large European study spanning decades has found that young men who were overweight at age 18 were as likely to die by 60 as light smokers, while obese teens, like heavy smokers, were at double the risk of dying early. While obesity is linked to a slew of health problems, the new findings fly in the face of numerous recent studies showing that people who are merely overweight may not be at higher risk of premature death than those of normal weight.
docs.snippet: Likening obesity's risks to those of smoking, a large European study spanning decades has found that young men who were overweight at age 18 were as likely to die by 60 as light smokers, while obese teens, like heavy smokers, were at double the risk...
